1-3
GARTER;
drawn by horses at a walking pace, are often mat at a gallop and always
in a brisk trot, with the carter standing in front and driving by reins;
Giddup up there, team; giddup, teams out of the way there, mister2 One
side, fellowS
NARHATORs
Omnibuses are numerous, many of them drawn by four horses0 Hackney
coaches are also abundant, and together with a few plain private car¬
riages, make up a crowd of conveyances bucketing over the bad pave¬
ments, and racketting and tarryhooting through the Hew York streets
with as much hubbub, hullabaloo, and general unmitigated uproar as
the most optimistic man might expect in a city seven times the size*
NAKRs
The whole of the population in the streets seem to enjoy this bustle,
end add to it by their own rapid pace, as if they were all going to
some place of appointment; as indeed some of them are:
HANs
Where you off to. Jack?
JACK;
Getting down to Courtlandt Street
HANs (SLIGHTLY
FURTHER OFF)
What you doing there?
JAGKs
Going to meet the packeto (CALLING OVER HIS SHOULIER)
HANs (FURTHER
STILL)
Which packet might that be?
JACK;
Packet from Providence (CALLING STILL FURTHER) Xtas the steamship
Presidents
HARR;
Everybody appears to be in motion, and everything else* The carriages
rattle through the streets; the carts dance as if they were running
races with them; the ladies trip along in all the colours of the rain¬
bow:
GIRL;
Lord, Mabel, skip into that door right smart, or I declare that carriage
